preLearning.activation: What birds do you see in your neighborhood? Let's learn their Spanish names!
preLearning.preview: You'll learn: flamenco, águila, gorrión, paloma, búho

content.title: Meet Your First Spanish Bird
content.noticing: Notice: It's similar to English 'flamingo' - this is called a cognate!
content.practice: Say it three times: el flamenco... el flamenco... el flamenco

content.instruction: Click on the flamingo in this wetland scene

feedback.incorrect: Not quite - look for the pink bird with long legs

dialogue: Guide: Sí, todos los flamencos son rosados.
content.practice: Repeat the dialogue, focusing on natural intonation

consolidation.review: Today you learned: el flamenco (flamingo) and how to describe its color

miniQuiz.q: How do you say 'the flamingo' in Spanish?

consolidation.reflection: Which was easier - recognizing the word or pronouncing it?

preLearning.activation: Think about different places where birds live - trees, water, mountains...
preLearning.preview: Learn to say: forest, lake, mountain, city, beach in Spanish

words.example: El águila vive en el bosque
Los patos nadan en el lago
El cóndor vuela sobre la montaña

content.level2: Complete: El flamenco vive en _____ (la laguna)
content.level3: Create: Write where your favorite bird lives

examples: El gorrión vive en la ciudad
Los flamencos viven en las lagunas
content.practice: Transform: El águila/vivir/montaña → El águila vive en la montaña

consolidation.productiveTask: Describe where three different birds live using the new vocabulary
consolidation.peerLearning: Share your sentences with a partner or in the app
consolidation.selfAssessment: Can you describe where 3 different birds live?

preLearning.activation: How would you describe a peacock? Big? Colorful? Beautiful?
preLearning.preview: Learn descriptive adjectives and how to combine them

content.agreement: Adjectives must match the gender and number of the noun

content.analysis: Notice how adjectives change endings to match the bird's gender/number

scaffold: Start with: Es un pájaro... (It's a bird...)
Add size: Es un pájaro grande...
Add color: Es un pájaro grande y negro...
Add habitat: Es un pájaro grande y negro que vive en las montañas
content.model: El cóndor es un pájaro muy grande y negro que vive en las montañas altas

consolidation.synthesis: Create a 'Bird ID Card' with name, size, color, and habitat
consolidation.reflection: Which adjective agreement rule is most challenging?
consolidation.extension: Learn specialized adjectives: majestuoso, elegante, feroz

modules.title: Bird Behaviors: What They Do
objectives: Learn action verbs for bird behaviors

preLearning.activation: Act out: flying, singing, hunting, nesting. Now let's learn these in Spanish!
preLearning.preview: Master verbs: volar, cantar, cazar, anidar

content.scenario: A day in the life of a bird
timeline: Por la mañana: El pájaro canta
Por la tarde: Vuela a su nido
content.practice: Narrate what the bird does using the verbs

content.script: Describe what you see: 'Aquí vemos un águila. El águila vuela sobre las montañas. Busca comida. ¡Mira! Ve un conejo. Baja rápidamente...'
content.support: Use provided verb bank and sentence starters

consolidation.production: Create a mini-documentary script about a bird's daily routine
consolidation.collaboration: Exchange scripts and provide peer feedback
consolidation.realWorld: Watch a Spanish nature documentary clip - identify verbs you learned

modules.title: Cultural Connections: Birds in Spanish Culture

preLearning.activation: Do you know any English expressions with birds? (early bird, eagle eye...)
preLearning.preview: Discover how Spanish uses birds in everyday expressions

expressions.usage: Mi profesor es un águila - nada se le escapa
expressions.cultural: Eagles represent keen vision and intelligence

expressions.spanish: Estar como pez en el agua
expressions.literal: To be like a fish in water
expressions.usage: María está como pez en el agua hablando español
expressions.cultural: Though not a bird, shows how animals express comfort

content.excerpt: Verde que te quiero verde / Verde viento. Verdes ramas
content.analysis: Birds often symbolize freedom and dreams in Spanish poetry
content.activity: Find bird imagery in the poem

content.insight: Spanish varies across regions - embrace the diversity!

consolidation.culturalProduct: Create a visual guide to bird expressions in Spanish
consolidation.research: Find a Spanish song or poem mentioning birds
consolidation.reflection: How do bird metaphors differ between English and Spanish?

pedagogicalFramework.approach: Communicative Language Teaching with Visual Support
